title: 103_s659
content: The Act may be cited as the "Radio Free Asia Act of 1993". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress supports the right to seek and share information globally, as stated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The US has long promoted accurate information and democratic ideals worldwide, including through Radio Free Europe, Radio Liberty, and Radio Marti broadcasting to Eastern Europe, the former Soviet Union, and Cuba. The introduction of similar radio broadcasting to China and other totalitarian states in Asia would increase the dissemination of accurate information and promote freedom, aligning with US foreign policy goals. Conducted professionally, it would bring closer the day when all major powers support freedom globally. The introduction of radio broadcasting in China and other totalitarian states in Asia would promote freedom and accurate information, aligning with US foreign policy goals to support freedom globally. This cooperation among major powers brings us closer to a world of cooperating democracies. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to support radio broadcasting to Asia. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to designate an organization for radio broadcasting to China, Burma, Cambodia, Laos, North Korea, Tibet, and Vietnam under the name 'Radio Free Asia'. The Board will consider recommendations from the Commission on Broadcasting to China. The authorities, responsibilities, and limitations for the Board, Comptroller General, Secretary of State, and Board of Directors of RFE/RL, Incorporated will apply to Radio Free Asia. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to designate an organization for radio broadcasting to Asia under the name 'Radio Free Asia'. Directors of RFE/RL, Incorporated in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union shall apply to the broadcasts by that organization in Asia. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to designate an organization for radio broadcasting to Asia under the name 'Radio Free Asia'. Directors of RFE/RL, Incorporated in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union shall apply to the broadcasts by that organization in Asia. SEC. 4. BOARD FOR INTERNATIONAL BROADCASTING. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to increase membership, with the number of members rising to fourteen, including two ex officio members. The chief operating executives of RFE/RL, Incorporated and a designated organization shall also be ex officio members of the Board. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to increase membership to fourteen members, including two ex officio members. Presidential appointees serve three-year terms, with additional voting members appointed for one, two, or three years to stagger terms. Presidential appointees serve three-year terms, with additional voting members appointed for staggered terms of one, two, or three years. Vacancies are filled by the President with Senate approval, and members can serve until their successor is appointed and qualified. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to increase membership to fourteen members, including two ex officio members. Ex officio members now referred to as "Each ex officio member" and can also serve as chief operative executive of a similar organization designated under section 15. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to increase membership to fourteen members, including two ex officio members who can also serve as chief operative executive of a similar organization designated under section 15. Additionally, there are conforming amendments made. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to establish an organization similar to RFE/RL, Incorporated for conducting radio broadcasting to totalitarian nations of Asia. Additionally, a Board for International Broadcasting is desirable to provide assistance to RFE/RL, Incorporated and similar organizations conducting radio broadcasting to totalitarian nations of Asia. The Board for International Broadcasting Act of 1973 is amended to establish an organization for radio broadcasting to totalitarian nations of Asia and to encourage dialog with various countries including the former Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, Afghanistan, China, Burma, Cambodia, Laos, North Korea, Tibet, and Vietnam.
